questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early diagnosis and treatment

 

Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in the management of breast cancer. This involves screening methods such as mammography, which can detect cancer at an early stage when it is more likely to be treated successfully. Early treatment can significantly improve survival rates and outcomes for patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Specific protection involves preventive measures that protect against specific diseases, such as vaccinations or using protective equipment. Currently, there is no vaccine or specific protective measure that can prevent breast cancer.

 

Option C. Disability limitation: Disability limitation is part of tertiary prevention and focuses on minimizing the impact of an ongoing illness that has already caused some level of disability. It involves strategies to prevent complications and further disability. This is more applicable after a disease has been diagnosed and is not the best level of prevention for breast cancer.

 

Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is also a part of tertiary prevention and aims to help individuals recover as much function as possible after a disease has caused disability. It includes therapies to restore physical, psychological, and social functioning. While important, it is not the best preventive strategy for breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

questions.text: In the infectious disease ward, you notice a multi-drug therapy packet placed neatly on a patient's bedside table. Based on the drug composition, which of the following diseases do you think the packet is intended to treat? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Leprosy

 

The given image shows the adult blister packet used in the treatment of leprosy.

 

 

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: TB treatment involves a different combination of drugs, typically including isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

 

Option C. Vaginal discharge: Treatment for vaginal discharge depends on the specific cause, such as bacterial, fungal, or protozoal infection, and usually involves single-agent therapy.

 

Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea treatment generally involves antibiotics like ceftriaxone and azithromycin, not a multi-drug blister packet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multi-drug therapy packets containing drugs like rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone are specifically intended for the treatment of leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the options was initiated to ensure complete immunization of children? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MISSION INDRADHANUSH INCLUDES

 

  1. Polio
  2. Diphtheria
  3. Pertussis
  4. Tetanus
  5. TB
  6. Measles
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Rota Virus
  9. MR
  10. IPV
  11. JE
  12. HiB
  13. PCV

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

choices.text: Insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year
Insurance cover of Rs 10 Lacs per family per year

questions.text: As per the Ayushman Bharat program, the following is not an inclusion: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insurance cover of Rs 10 Lacs per family per year

 

Explanation:

 

The Ayushman Bharat program has two main components:

 

  • Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs) - Create a network of health, wellness infrastructure delivering comprehensive primary healthcare services
  • Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY). PM-JAY provides an insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year for secondary and tertiary hospitalization. This program is targeted towards the below poverty line (BPL) population, aiming to cover around 10.74 crore families.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year: This is included under PM-JAY.

 

Option B. Health and wellness centres: These are established to provide comprehensive primary healthcare services.

 

Option C. Meant for BPL families: The program targets families below the poverty line, aiming to benefit around 50 crore individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ayushman Bharat program includes an insurance cover of Rs 5 Lacs per family per year, health and wellness centres, and is meant for BPL families. An insurance cover of Rs 10 Lacs per family per year is not included.

questions.text: A city school board is determining the minimum classroom space per student for safety and well-being. What is the minimum per capita space that should be available for each child in a school classroom based on public health guidelines? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. > 10 Sqft

 

The minimum per capita space required for each child in a school classroom is greater than 10 square feet, ensuring adequate space for safety and comfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

School health service guidelines recommendations are:

 

  • One class room for maximum 40 students
  • Minus type desk
  • Doors and windows ≥ 25% of floor area
  • 1 urinal /60 student, 1 latrine/100 student.
  • Natural light from left side
  • Minimum area 10 sq. ft. per student for sitting.
  • School health examination every 6 months.
  • Walls should be white in colour.
  • Canteen should be present if number of students are more than 250.

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3000, rf=2

 

Calculation -  

 

Requirement of Amlodipine

 

40 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 1200 Tablets

 

Requirement of Lisinopril

 

10 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 300 Tablets

 

Reorder factor (Rf) for drugs supplied every:

 

  • 1 Month - 2
  • 3 Months - 6
  • 6 Months – 12

 

For the given question,

 

Total of 1500 tablets are required and reorder factor is 2

 

Hence, Total tablets required = (1200 + 300) x 2 = 3000 Tablets

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.

choices.text: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.text: You're an intern in a bustling hospital laboratory. As you're overseeing the day's activities, you notice that a newly appointed technician accidentally spills a blood sample on the floor. The technician, looking panicked, turns to you for guidance. Given the potential risks associated with blood spills, what is the most immediate and appropriate action you should instruct the technician to take? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Clean with absorbable material

 

  • In this situation, the next crucial action to take is to utilize absorbent material for cleaning up the spilled blood. Once the cleaning is complete, the used absorbent material should be disposed of in the designated yellow bin. Subsequently, a sodium hypochlorite solution is employed to thoroughly decontaminate the affected surface. The specific concentrations of sodium hypochlorite employed are as follows:
    • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces
    • >10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 dilution

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Call the infection control team of the hospital: While important, this is not the immediate action to take to contain the spill.

 

Option B. Mop it: Mopping without proper absorbent material and decontamination procedures could spread the contamination.

 

Option C. Cover it with 1% sodium hypochlorite: This step should follow the initial clean-up with absorbent material to ensure thorough decontamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypochlorites in Hospital waste Management

 

  • Disinfection of countertops and floors
  • Decontamination of blood spills
  • Irrigating agent in endodontic treatment
  • Disinfectant for manikins, laundry, dental appliances, hydrotherapy tanks
  • Treatment of liquid medical waste before disposal
  • Decontaminating water distribution systems in dialysis

questions.text: After a road traffic accident case has been admitted, there is a blood spillage on the hospital floor. Which type of disinfectant would you select for cleaning the floor? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sodium hypochlorite

 

If there is spillage of blood on the hospital floor, sodium hypochlorite is the recommended disinfectant for cleaning the floor.

 

Procedure to be followed in the event of blood/body fluid spillage:

 

  1. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves
  2. Broken glass (if any) of the container is cleaned first using tongs or a pan and brush and discarded in the sharp container. Caution is taken to not use hands.
  3. Disposable paper towels are used to absorb as much as possible.
  4. Water and detergent are used to clean the surface until visibly clean.
  5. The area is saturated with 0.5% Sodium Hypochlorite. This is prepared by diluting 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach at a 1:10 ratio.
  6. The tongs, pan, and brush are washed under running water and left to dry
  7. The gloves are removed and discarded.
  8. Hands are washed with soap and water using proper technique and dried with a disposable towel.
  9. The spillage is recorded in an incident book.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl alcohol: Is not recommended for cleaning surfaces with blood spills as it is less effective against some microorganisms and may evaporate too quickly.

 

Option B. Chlorhexidine: is also less effective against blood-borne pathogens and is better suited for skin disinfection.

 

Option D. Formaldehyde: Is not commonly used as a disinfectant due to its potential health hazards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective disinfection of surfaces contaminated with blood spills, sodium hypochlorite is the preferred choice due to its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to neutralize blood-borne pathogens.

choices.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution
Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries
To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.text: You are a researcher studying global mortality rates, and you notice substantial differences in the age structures of various countries. Recognizing that direct comparisons could be misleading due to these differences, you explore methods to equalize or adjust the mortality data to get a more accurate comparative view. In your research, you come across the term "standardized age mortality ratio." Which of the following best describes this concept? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution 

 

The standardized age mortality ratio serves as an indicator for the population's mortality rate adjusted to a standardized age distribution.

 

Standardization of Death Rates

 

  • While comparison of death rates of two populations, ‘crude death rate is not the right yardstick’, as age-compositions are different
  • Age-adjustment or age-standardization removes confounding effect of different age structures
  • Standardization may be direct or indirect
  • Standardization is carried out beginning by using a ‘Standard Population’

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution: Incorrect. Standardization typically adjusts for age, not sex.

 

Option C. Removal of bias due to different age group populations in different countries: Incorrect. This describes the purpose of age standardization, not the definition of standardized age mortality ratio.

 

Option D. To eliminate age structure of different countries: Incorrect. Age standardization accounts for, but does not eliminate, age structure differences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standardized age mortality ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, allowing for more accurate comparisons between populations with different age structures.

 

Additional Information

 

Types of Standardized Death Rates

 

Direct standardization:

 

  • Method:
    • Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied 
    • on a standard population
    • Total expected deaths calculated
    • Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • Feasibility:
    • Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR)
    • Availability of population in each age group

 

Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form

 

  • Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population
  • Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers
  • Examples of indirect Standardization:

  • Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100

  • Life Table Analysis

  • Survival Analysis

questions.text:
Examine the list of features given: [INICET MAY 2024]

 

  1. Delayed skin pinch
  2. Lethargy
  3. Thirst
  4. Sunken eyes
  5. Reduced Urine output

 

The features of some dehydration include:
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 3, 4

 

According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three types: no dehydration, some dehydration, and severe dehydration.

 

  • Some Dehydration: This condition is diagnosed when there are at least two of the following four signs: thirst, sunken eyes, delayed skin pinch (skin pinch goes back slowly), and restlessness or irritability. These signs indicate a moderate level of dehydration where the body is starting to show physical symptoms, but it has not yet progressed to a severe state.
  • In the question:
    • Delayed skin pinch (option 1) is one of the signs.
    • Thirst (option 3) is another sign.
    • Sunken eyes (option 4) is also a recognized sign of some dehydration.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option B, which includes all the relevant features (1, 3, and 4).

 

Other Options:

 

2: Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • According to the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three levels based on specific signs and symptoms:

questions.text: Under categorization of triage, the immediately life-threatening injuries would be classified as under the color-coded category: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Red

 

The triage system is used in disaster management to categorize victims based on the severity of their condition and the likelihood of survival. Immediate life-threatening injuries, where a person could die or develop severe complications if no intervention is made within 0 to 6 hours, are classified under the Red category. This category is designated for emergent cases that require immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This category is for urgent cases where intervention is needed within 6 to 24 hours, such as resuscitation or limb/life-saving surgery. Although these injuries are serious, they are not as immediately life-threatening as those in the Red category.

 

Option C. Green: This category is for non-urgent cases involving minor injuries like fractures, bruises, or lacerations. Patients in this category are ambulatory and can wait for treatment.

 

Option D. Black: This category is for patients who are either deceased or moribund (about to die). It represents the least priority in triage, as these patients have little to no chance of survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage Tagging system

questions.text:
A woman presents to a clinic with her son, Ram, who has developed symptoms consistent with Measles, including fever and rash. She mentions that Ram's brother, Shyam, exhibited similar symptoms a few days earlier. Which of the following statements regarding the situation are accurate? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Ram is the index case
  2. Shyam is primary case
  3. Ram got infected from Shyam
  4. If mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All are correct

 

Index case: The first case that comes to the notice of the investigator. In this situation, Ram is the index case as he is the one presented to the clinic first.

 

Primary case: The first case of a disease in a population. Shyam, who exhibited symptoms a few days earlier, is the primary case.

 

Transmission: Given the incubation period of measles (7 to 18 days), it is likely that Ram got infected from Shyam, who was in an infectious state.

 

Post-exposure prophylaxis: If the mother had reported Shyam's infection, Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis. This can be in the form of a measles vaccine within 72 hours of exposure or immunoglobulin up to 6 days post-exposure.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Index case → First case that comes to the notice of investigator.
  • Primary case → First case of a disease in a population.
  • Incubation period of measles infection is 7 to 18 days
  • Vaccine can be given within 72 hours of post-exposure and immunoglobulin can be given up to 6 days’ post-exposure.

questions.text: According to our national immunization schedule, when should the first dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine ideally be administered to a neonate? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. At birth

 

At birth the following vaccines are given: BCG, OPV-0 dose & HEP B.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine is administered at birth as part of the national immunization schedule. This early vaccination is crucial for preventing mother-to-child transmission of the Hepatitis B virus, which can occur during birth or shortly after. Administering the vaccine at birth significantly reduces the risk of the newborn contracting Hepatitis B, a critical intervention in areas with a high prevalence of the disease.
